file.file-caption: Figure 1. Age-adjusted incidence rates (cases per million individuals per year) of conjunctival melanoma (CM) during 1992-2010 in (A) Both sexes: the mean age-standardized incidence rate of CM in Canada was 0.32 cases per million individuals per year, the slope of the line was 0.003 ± 0.0042 cases per million individuals per year; p=0.48.(B) For males: the mean age-standardized incidence rate of CM was 0.35 cases per million males per year, the slope of the line was 0.0002±0.0074 cases per million individuals per year; p=0.98. (C) For females: the mean age-standardized incidence rate of CM was 0.29 cases per million individuals per year, the slope of the line was 0.0056±0.0068 cases per million females per year; p=0.42.

abstract.title: Abstract
Background:
abstract.p: Melanoma is the most common primary malignancy of the eye in adults. While the epidemiology of uveal melanoma has recently been described in Canada, little is known about the epidemiology and geographic distribution of patients with conjunctival melanoma (CM) patients in Canada.
abstract.title: Methods:
abstract.p: We conducted a population-based study of CM incidence across all Canadian provinces and territories during 1992 – 2010 using two independent population-based registries.
abstract.title: Results:
abstract.p: 190 patients were diagnosed with CM in Canada from 1992% –to 2010. 55.3 % of these patients were malesmen. The mean annual incidence rate of CM in Canada was 0.32 cases per million individuals (0.35 and 0.29 cases per million individuals for malesmen and femaleswomen, respectively). The incidence rates for Canadian provinces demonstrated that the eastern provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick had higher age-adjusted incidence rates than the national average, with rates of 0.52 and 0.47 cases per million individuals per year, respectively.
abstract.title: Conclusions:
abstract.p: This analysis demonstrates novel variations in CM incidence rates between different Canadian provinces. These results taken together with the data reported from the United StatesSA confirm the North -to -South geographic gradient of increasing CM incidence. This research highlights that the epidemiology of CM in North America is comparable to that of cutaneous malignant melanoma in contrast to the trends for uveal melanoma distribution.

body.p: Feras M. Ghazawi MD, Ph.D1, Rami Darwich Ph.D2, Michelle Le B.Sc2, Abdulhadi Jfri MD2, Elham Rahme Ph.D3, Julia Valdemarin Burnier, Ph.D4, Denis Sasseville MD, FRCPC2, Miguel N. Burnier Jr. MD, Ph.D, FRCPC4 and Ivan V. Litvinov MD, Ph.D, FRCPC2
1Division of Dermatology, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
2Division of Dermatology, McGill University, Montréal, Québec, Canada.
3Division of Clinical Epidemiology, McGill University, Montréal, Québec, Canada.
4Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
Correspondence: Ivan V. Litvinov, M.D., Ph.D., FRCPC, Rm. E02.6236, 1001 Decarie Blvd, Montréal, Québec, H4A 3J1 Phone: 514-934-1934 x76140, Fax: 514-843-1570 email: ivan.litvinov@mcgill.ca.
Competing Interests Statement:
Competing Interests Statement: The authors declare no competing financial interests.

Feras M. Ghazawi, Rami Darwich, Michelle Le: obtained/tabulated the data and co-wrote the paper; Abdulhadi Jfri - analyzed the data and plotted the figures; Elham Rahme- performed statistical analyses; Julia Valdemarin Burnier, Denis Sasseville, Miguel N. Burnier and Ivan V. Litvinov- Developed/supervised the study, analyzed the data and co-wrote the paper.
Submission Type: Brief article – Clinical science

Précis: This analysis of 190 patients defines incidence trends for conjunctival melanoma in Canada, highlights important geographic difference in the distribution of this malignancy and confirms the existence of a North to South geographic incidence gradient in North America.
body.title: Introduction
body.p: Melanoma is the most common primary malignancy of the eye in adults. While the majority of ocular melanomas occur within the uveal tract, the remainder arise from non-uveal sites, predominantly from the conjunctiva. We have recently reported a detailed account on the incidence trends for uveal melanoma in Canada, which has demonstrated a steady annual increase.1 Conjunctival melanoma (CM) is a potentially devastating malignancy that arises from melanocytes located in the basal layer of the conjunctiva. CM is associated with a high risk of local recurrence.2 It can invade the conjunctiva and spread systemically through lymphatics or haematogenously.3 4 Previous reports indicate that CM comprises of ~5% of ocular melanomas.5 In this brief report, we highlight the burden of CM in Canada to contribute to the literature on this rare, but potentially deadly cancer.
body.title: Methods:

p.named-content: This study was conducted in accordance with protocols approved by the Social

named-content.data-match: Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada
named-content.named-content: Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada

named-content.data-match: Québec Inter-University Centre for Social Statistics
named-content.named-content: Québec Inter-University Centre for Social Statistics

p.named-content: ), respectively, with protocol numbers CISS-RDC-668035 and 13-SSH-MCG-3749-S001. In addition, this study received an exemption from the McGill University Research Ethics Board review.

body.p: Briefly, we examined the data on incidence of CM using two distinct population-based cancer registries (Canadian Cancer Registry (CCR) and Le Registre Québécois du Cancer (LRQC)) during 1992–2010 using International Classification of Diseases for Oncology (ICD-O-3) codes for the conjunctiva as primary tumortumour site (C69.0). The study was conducted in a similar manner as previously reported for other malignancies.1 6–121 6–11 The CCR is a dynamic registry of Canadian residents from 12 Canadian provinces and territories (excluding Québec), who have been diagnosed with primary tumours from 1992 to 2013. LRQC is a cancer registry for Québec residents that provides data from 1992 to 2010. For consistency, the study was conducted from 1992 to 2010 to include all Canadian provinces and territories for the same period.

Several confidentiality rules apply to CCR and LRQC data prior to its publication to protect patient confidentiality, such as the random rounding of variables where counts had to be rounded to a multiples of 5 using an unbiased rounding scheme, as previously described.1 6 7 11 121 6 7 9 11 121 6 7 9 11
body.title: Results

title.named-content: Demographic Characteristics of Canadian CM patients
Demographic characteristics of Canadian cm patients with CM

body.p: 190One hundred and ninety patients were diagnosed with CM, accounting for 7% of all ocular melanoma cases in Canada within the aforementioned period. Of the 190 patients, 105 were malesen (55% of all CM patients with CM). The sex-standardizedstandardised male -to -female incidence rate ratio (IRR) was 1.26:1.00 (Table 1table 1).

caption.title: Demographic characteristics of conjunctival melanoma (CM) patients with conjunctival melanoma (CM) in Canada diagnosed during 1992–2010. Age-adjusted incidence rates are reported per . age-adjusted incidence rates are reported per 1 million individuals.

td.p: Median age of diagnosis for CM in both sexes
Median age of diagnosis for CM in males
Median age of diagnosis for CM in females

p.named-content: Age-adjusted incidence rates are reported per 1 million individuals.

fn.p: Rounded to a multiple of 5 as per Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC)/Statistics Canada regulations.
Data could not be released by the SSHRC/Québec Inter-University Centre for Social StatisticsQICSS due to small counts of patients in these provinces/territories/age groups.

body.p: The majority of CM patients with CM (58%) were ≥60 at the time of diagnosis, while 32% of patients were 40–59 years old. Only 11% of patients were younger than 40. The median age at the time of diagnosis was 66.5 years (60.5 in malesen and 69.0 in femaleswomen) (Table 1table 1).

title.named-content: Incidence and geographic distribution of CM cases in Canada during 1992-2010
Incidence and geographic distribution of cmCM cases in Canada during 1992–-2010

body.p: The mean age-standardizedstandardised incidence rate of CM in Canada was 0.32 cases per million individuals per year (95% CI: 0.28 to 0.37). Notably, CM incidence rates were stable over time with the slope of <0.01 cases per million individuals per year (p=0.3248) (Figure 1Afigure 1A). Mean age-standardizedstandardised incidence rate for malesmen and femaleswomen were 0.35 and 0.29 cases per million individuals per year, respectively (Figures 1B and 1Cfigure 1B and C). The male:female IRR was also stable during the study period.

caption.title: Age-adjusted incidence rates (cases per million individuals per year) of conjunctival melanoma (CM) during 1992–2010 in. (A) Both sexes: the mean age-standardizedstandardised incidence rate of CM in Canada was 0.32 cases per million individuals per year, and the slope of the line was 0.003±0.0042 cases per million individuals per year; p=0.48. (B) For males: the mean age-standardizedstandardised incidence rate of CM was 0.35 cases per million males per year, and the slope of the line was 0.0002±0.0074 cases per million individuals per year; p=0.98. (C) For females: the mean age-standardizedstandardised incidence rate of CM was 0.29 cases per million individuals per year, and the slope of the line was 0.0056±0.0068 cases per million females per year; p=0.42.

body.p: The incidence rates for the Canadian provinces demonstrated that the eastern provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick had higher incidence rates than the national average: 0.52 and 0.47 cases per million individuals per year, respectively (Table 1table 1).
body.title: Discussion
body.p: We report, for the first time, the incidence trends of CM in Canada using population-based cancer registry data to assess the burden of this malignancy in this country. CM has previously been documented to preferentially affect individuals>60 (54% of patients in one study)12 with the mean age at the time of diagnosis of 57.4 years.13 Similarly, our results further confirm these trends in the Canadian population. Our analysis also indicates a stable incidence of CM over the period of 1992–2010, with a mean age-adjusted rate of 0.32 cases per million individuals per year (95% CI: 0.28 to 0.37). This is consistent with a report from Germany which showed a stable incidence of CM from 1960 to 1988.14 Similarly, stable incidence rates of CM were reported in Korea from 1999 to 2011.15 The Canadian CM incidence rate closely mirrors the incidence rate found in the USAnited States, which was reported to be 0.4 cases per million individuals per year from 1996- to 2000.16 In Sweden, the incidence rates of CM between 1960– and 2005 ranged 0.10–0.74 and 0.06–0.45 cases per million individuals per year in men and women, respectively.17

The sex-specific trends showing higher rates of CM in malesen in Canada (IRR of 1.26:1.00) were consistent with the reported trends in the United StatesSA (male -to -female IRR of 1.29:1.00).16 Similarly, 56% of patients diagnosed with CM in Finland from 1967 to 2000 were malesen (compared tocompared with the 55.3% reported here for the Canadian population). Notably, incidence trends over time indicate stable rates in both sexes. Conflicting reports in the literature on the incidence trends globally have been described. Significant increasing trends of CM incidence in white men (but not in white women) in the United StatesSA have been demonstrated.18 Further, the incidence of CM was reported to have increased in Finland from 0.4 to 0.8 cases per million individuals per year between 1967 to 2000.19 Increasing CM incidence rates were also reported in Sweden17 and Denmark.20

The incidence of CM was the highest in the eastern provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. This result is in contrast to the distribution of uveal melanoma patients with uveal melanoma, where the provinces of British Columbia and Saskatchewan had higher incidence rates than the national average.1 This finding suggests that risk factors for both malignancies are distinct. It is worth noting that Nova Scotia and New Brunswick provinces had significantly elevated incidence rates of cutaneous malignant melanoma within the same period of time, where Nova Scotia had the highest incidence rate of cutaneous melanoma in the country in 1992–2010.11 Parallel trend of CM incidence to its cutaneous counterpart may be attributed to increased impact of ultraviolet radiation exposure in the Atlantic provinces. This correlation in the elevated incidence of both CM and cutaneous melanoma in Nova Scotia further supports sunlight exposure as a key risk factor for CM. In fact, similar patterns of simultaneous increase in the incidence rates of cutaneous and conjunctival melanomaCM were also reported in the USAnited States,18 21 Sweden17 and Finland.19 This trend might have been missed in other reports, where CM data wasere combined with the results for uveal melanoma.18

Race is another important risk factor for developing CM. In fact, in one population-based study, the annual age-adjusted incidence rates of conjunctival melanomaCM per million population per year was reported to be 0.15 in Asians, 0.17 in American Indians, 0.18 in African-Americans, 0.33 in Hispanics and 0.49 non-Hispanic Caucasians.22 Variations in the racial distribution of inhabitants for the Canadian provinces may— -at least in part- —explain disparities in CM incidence across the country. Specifically, a significant percentage of inhabitants of the provinces of high incidence Nova Scotia and New Brunswick are Caucasians of European (English-French) descent. On the other hand, a significant proportion of self-identified visible minorities reside in provinces of low incidence of CM including Ontario and Quebec (online supplementary table 1online supplementary tables 1; 1online supplementary table 1).

Finally, it is worth noting that the rates of CM incidence are higher in the United StatesSA than in Canada, consistent with the reported North–-South gradient of increasing incidence of cutaneous malignant melanoma in North America11 and further in keeping with the parallel relationship between conjunctival and cutaneous malignant melanoma.

This study had several important limitations. There isare no available data in the examined registries on CM patients’ race and clinical stage of patients with CM at the time of diagnosis. CM has been shown to affect Caucasian individuals at a higher rate than other races.23 Therefore, we were not able to confirm the differences in CM incidence and clinical stage between different races (Caucasians in particular). Furthermore, overall small counts as well as data rounding limited our ability to produce definitive conclusions regarding trends and regional variations on CM incidence.

In conclusion, we presented an analysis of CM incidence in the Canadian population and demonstrated, for the first time, previously unrecognizedunrecognised variations in incidence between different provinces. The incidence of CM in Canada was concordant with the data from the United StatesSA, demonstrating geographical continuity for CM incidence between the North American countries and existing North -to -South gradient of increasing incidence of CM with decreasing latitude. Importantly, this research highlights that the epidemiology of CM in North America parallels cutaneous malignant melanoma and not uveal melanoma trends, as expected. This work is fundamental to the understanding epidemiology and risk factors of CM globally.
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
We thank all the staff that administer the data registries included in this analysis. The interpretation, analysis and reporting of these data are the sole responsibility of the authors.
FUNDING SOURCES:

This work was supported by the Cole Foundation Grant to Dr. Litvinov, Canadian Dermatology Foundation research grants to Dr. Sasseville and Dr. Litvinov and the Fonds de la recherche en santé du Québec (FRSQ# 34 753 and 36769) research grants to Dr. Litvinov. No funding bodies had any role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.

email-content.mail-subject: Proof of your article for British Journal of Ophthalmology - 10.1136/bjophthalmol-2019-313977

mail-body.p: I’m pleased to provide the proof of your article, which is available on our author proofing system here:

Please submit any corrections then ensure you click ‘Approve’ to complete the author proofing process. Signing off the paper will send the article back to the Production team so they can make any changes.
Please note, the online author proofing system cannot be used in the browser Internet Explorer. Please review your proofs in Google Chrome.

A PDF version of the proof is available to download and review, but all corrections must be submitted using the online system. Please contact us at production.bjo@bmj.com if you need any help using this.

This is the only opportunity you will have to correct your article before publication, so please review it carefully. Please ensure you respond to queries listed in the article. Minor errors cannot be corrected after publication and any serious scientific errors will result in a formal correction.
Reprints: If you wish to purchase reprints of your article, please fill in the reprint form.
British Journal of Ophthalmology Production Team
